page.title: 16OLD BUILDINGS IN BROMYARD
page.content: {Bromyard}was featured in the original{Domesday Book}and every Summer many tourists visit the town. {St.Peter's Church,}is a 12th century Saxon building. The{Public {Library}and{Magistrates' Court buildings were built in the 19th century. {Dumbleton Hall}is a 17th century stone house, apparently built as a Magistrates' Court with cells underneath. The{Hop-pole Hotel}in the old market square is Georgian. Many 16th century houses have had Georgian facades added. Timber was an important local building material in the 1600s.{Tower {House}on Tower Hill built in 1630 is a particularly fine example of a timber framed house.{Charles I}is said to have rested here in 1645.
